text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

Subsection 9.7.2.7.3(3) is re-written in accordance with The Executive Office of Asset Forfeiture, Department of the Treasury (TEOAF) issued Directive No. 34, Policy Limiting the Federal Adoption of Seizures by State and Local Law Enforcement Agencies, dated January 16, 2015.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This IRM supersedes IRM 9.7.2 dated March 3, 2015. This IRM also incorporates procedure(s) implemented by the Director, Operations Policy and Support, guidance memorandum dated April 16, 2015, [Subject: “Additional Guidance on TEOAF Directive No 34-Policy Limiting the Federal Adoption of Seizures by State and Local Law Enforcement Agencies”].

) Civil forfeiture is an in rem proceeding against the property itself, not the of property. Civil forfeiture is a process that is separated from, and not dependent on, a criminal prosecution. Civil forfeiture can proceed tively or judicially. (

) All civil forfeiture statutes presently in effect are in rem statutes in which the property itself, not the owner of the property, is accused of wrongdoing. For that reason, only property that was actually used to commit, or was derived from, an offense, or property traceable to it, is subject to forfeiture. (

applies in any civil forfeiture action in which the subject property is cash, monetary instruments in bearer form, funds deposited in account in a financial institution, or precious metals. Any identical property found in the same place or account as the property involved in the offense is the basis for the forfeiture shall be subject to forfeiture under
USC a. For example, suppose a person placed $
in laundered funds in a bank account on Monday and the account is seized for civil forfeiture Friday. Suppose also that at the time of the seizure, the balance in the account is $
, but that in between, on Wednesday, the balance dropped to zero and $
in unlaundered funds are deposited, so the $
seized cannot be strictly traced back to the money offense. In general, the $
seized on Friday was not the same money as the laundered funds that were placed in the account on Monday. Failing the tracing requirement, the government would not be able to forfeit the $

Any civil forfeiture action pursuant to 18 USC §984 must be commenced not more than 1 year from the date of the offense.
Seizure and Forfeiture

) The process of civil forfeiture begins with the actual or constructive seizure the allegedly “guilty” property. Actual seizure of tangible personal property of Property for quently occurs prior to the initiation of a formal civil forfeiture action. (
) Because there are numerous issues involved beyond the legality to execute seizure and commence a forfeiture action, IRM
, Pre-Seizure Planning, Planning has been devoted entirely to pre-seizure planning. (
) Property subject to forfeiture under
USC §
) may be seized pursuant to the methods described below as authorized in
USC of Seizure for (b)(
), and (j). (
) Property subject to forfeiture may be seized pursuant to a warrant obtained the same manner as provided for a search warrant under Rule
of the Warrant Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure (Fed. R. Crim. P.
). The AUSA must submit an application for the seizure of particular property, as well as a agent’s sworn affidavit setting forth the facts that provide probable cause for the seizure. (

) A seizure warrant may be issued in any judicial district in which a civil action against the property may be filed, and may be executed in any judicial district in which the property is found. In the event that an out-of-district is contemplated, it must involve consultation and coordination with the US torney’s Office and the field office within the judicial district in which the is to occur. (
) Title
USC §

requires that civil forfeiture of real property proceed judi- cially. Except as provided in the statute, the real property that is the subject a civil forfeiture action cannot be seized before entry of an order of forfeiture. Note: The owners or occupants of the real property cannot be evicted absent notice and a hearing or an ex parte determination that there is probable cause for the forfeiture and that there are exigent circumstances that the seizure of the property without prior notice and an opportunity for the property owner to be heard. (

) Property may be seized where a complaint for forfeiture has been filed in US district court and the court has issued a warrant of arrest in rem. A warrant of Arrest In Rem arrest in rem must be issued for the arrest of any asset that is to be forfeited a civil judicial forfeiture proceeding. It is not appropriate to use a warrant of arrest in rem when property is to be forfeited administratively, because it is issued only after judicial forfeiture proceedings have been formally commenced. (

) A warrant of arrest in rem is issued by the clerk of the court when a of forfeiture is filed. The complaint must describe with “reasonable the property involved, the place of seizure, and other allegations as required by the statute on which the forfeiture is based. (
) A warrant of arrest in rem is necessary for civil forfeiture even if the property already in custody pursuant to an earlier seizure, in order to provide the with jurisdiction over the property.
F (
) Internal Revenue Manual

a civil forfeiture action cannot be seized before entry of an order of forfeiture. Note: The owners or occupants of the real property cannot be evicted absent notice and a hearing or an ex parte determination that there is probable cause for the forfeiture and that there are exigent circumstances that permit the seizure of the property without prior notice and an opportunity for the property owner to be heard. (

) Property may be seized where a complaint for forfeiture has been filed in US district court and the court has issued a warrant of arrest in rem. A warrant of arrest in rem must be issued for the arrest of any asset that is to be forfeited in a civil judicial forfeiture proceeding. It is not appropriate to use a warrant of arrest in rem when property is to be forfeited administratively, because it is issued only after judicial forfeiture proceedings have been formally commenced. (

) A warrant of arrest in rem is issued by the clerk of the court when a complaint of forfeiture is filed. The complaint must describe with “reasonable particularity” the property involved, the place of seizure, and other allegations as required by the statute on which the forfeiture is based. (

) A warrant of arrest in rem is necessary for civil forfeiture even if the property is already in custody pursuant to an earlier seizure, in order to provide the court with jurisdiction over the property.
Asset Seizure and (

) Where a civil forfeiture action is filed in a judicial district other than the district where the property is located, the court’s authority to have a arrest in rem served on the property is based on the nationwide service provision of
USC §

) State and local agencies generally request Federal adoption when, after making a seizure, they determine that a state forfeiture proceeding is not possible or that a Federal forfeiture proceeding would be more (
) Adoptive seizures are only those seizures where

% of the pre-seizure activity and related investigations are performed by the state or local agency before a request is made for adoption. There must be a state and a Federal basis for forfeiture in order for the seizure to be true Seizures resulting from joint investigations or task force cases are not seizures. (
) The Executive Office of Asset Forfeiture, Department of the Treasury Directive Number
, Policy Limiting the Federal Adoption of Seizures by and Local Law Enforcement Agencies, sets general policies and with respect to adoptions. Directive Number

is located on the Warrants Forfeiture web site. The policies covered include: a. circumstances for considering adopting a seizure b. list of property that implicates public safety concerns c. list of property that is prohibited from adoption d. requirements for an adoption of property that is not listed; however, believes property implicates public safety e. circumstances for which this policy does not apply (
) The general adoption procedures in Directive Number
cover the adoption form, Request for Adoption of State or Local Seizure (see Exhibit

) Criminal Investigation requires a legal review of the adoption by a Criminal (CT) Attorney prior to taking custody of any seized assets from a state or agency. Criminal Investigation also requires that a seizure warrant be in state and local adoptions. (
) The court may enter a restraining order to take any other action to the availability of property subject to civil forfeiture upon the filing of a civil Orders and feiture complaint. Orders (

) The court may also enter a restraining order to take any other action to preserve the ability of property subject to civil forfeiture before the filing of complaint if, after notice to persons with an interest in the property and tunity for a hearing, the court determines that: a. There is a substantial probability that the United States will prevail on issue of forfeiture and that failure to enter the order will result in the property being destroyed, removed from the jurisdiction of the court, otherwise made unavailable for forfeiture. b. The need to preserve the availability of the property through the entry the requested order outweighs the hardship on any party against the order is to be entered. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

a. and Forfeiture
page (
) An order entered before the filing of a complaint is effective for not more than
days, unless extended by the court for good cause shown. (

) A temporary restraining order may be entered upon application of the United States without notice or opportunity for a hearing before the filing of a complaint. A temporary restraining order shall expire not more than
days after the date it is entered, unless extended for good cause shown or unless the party against whom it is entered consents to an extension for a longer period. (

) Property subject to forfeiture, other than real property, may be seized without warrant if there is probable cause to believe that the property is subject to for- a feiture and: a. the seizure is made pursuant to a lawful arrest or search, and b. exigent circumstances exist creating the need to act promptly to prevent removal, destruction, or concealment of forfeitable property (

) Special agents should attempt seizures without a warrant only after carefully considering the circumstances with which they are confronted, and should consult legal counsel, if time permits. Such seizures should only be made if exigent circumstances prohibiting the timely obtainment of a seizure warrant can be clearly documented. (
) Whenever possible, CI’s forfeiture activity will concentrate on utilizing
USC §

)(A). However, there are situations where the subject is involved in money laundering activity; but, due to varying circumstances, only a portion of the assets can be traced to specific money laundering transactions. It would inefficient to pursue forfeiture under two separate statutes, a portion of the assets under
USC §
)(A) (Financial Transaction) and a portion under
USC §
)(C) (Constitutes or is Derived from Proceeds). With the concurrence of the AUSA assigned to the investigation,
USC §

)(C) can be used for the entire forfeiture. This forfeiture authority would also apply to Specified Unlawful Activity (SUA) proceeds seized during legitimate money laundering investigation where none of the proceeds can be traced to money laundering transactions. Criminal Investigation has authority forfeit property derived from proceeds traceable to SUA pursuant to
USC §
)(C). The ability to forfeit assets under
USC §
)(C) is designed to support, not supplant the primary statutes (forfeitures relative to financial transactions;
USC §

)(A)) within the statutory jurisdiction of CI, and should only be utilized in investigations to which CI has devoted resources toward investigating money laundering violations. Forfeiture actions in which
USC §
)(C) will be utilized will be approved at the Special Agent in Charge (SAC) level; however, such actions will be subject to periodic review. (
) The following guidelines set forth the circumstances governing the exercise of this authority and applicable procedures: a. Use of forfeiture authority under
USC §
)(C) must be incidental to a legitimate money laundering investigation. This means the basis for any proposed forfeiture of property under §

was developed in the course of an investigation of a particular subject(s) regarding potential money laundering violation(s) or the financial transaction(s) being investi- gated as a potential money laundering violation(s). Internal Revenue Manual
a. Use of forfeiture authority under
USC §
)(C) must be incidental to a legitimate money laundering investigation. This means the basis for any proposed forfeiture of property under §

was developed in the course of an investigation of a particular subject(s) regarding potential money laundering violation(s) or the financial transaction(s) being investi- gated as a potential money laundering violation(s).

)(C) will be limited to in money laundering investigations where no reasonable forfeiture tive is available for the agency, i.e., proof required to forfeit under §

)(A) (property involving in or traceable to a money laundering transaction) is lacking. These situations typically arise when the subject property cannot be traced to a specific financial transaction. c. The ability to forfeit SUA proceeds under
USC §

in personal property unlimited as to cash) and judicial seizure investigations with the ment and concurrence of the AUSA assigned to the investigation. Administrative forfeitures under these provisions include circumstances involving plea agreements and negotiated settlements and instances where the AUSA assigned to the investigation recommends the trative forfeiture process be utilized. (

) The Asset Forfeiture Coordinator (AFC) will not send notice until a CT has prepared and submitted a Law and Fact Memorandum to the SAC sup- porting the administrative forfeiture. If a CT attorney is not permitted to a Law and Fact because of grand jury material, the AFC will inform the and send notice. (

) If notice is not sent to the person from whom the property was seized within days from the date of seizure and one of the exceptions does not apply, the property must be returned to the person from whom it was seized. forfeiture proceedings may be commenced again at a later time. (
) Contraband or other property that the person from whom the property was seized may not legally possess will not be returned. (
) A one

-day extension period for sending notice may be granted by the Associate Director, Warrants and Forfeiture, only if there is reason to that the notice may have an adverse result. A request to extend the period time for sending notice should be sent by memorandum from the SAC, ex- plaining the need for the extension based on one or more of the following conditions: a. endangering the life or physical safety of an individual b. flight from prosecution c. destruction of or tampering with evidence d. intimidation of potential witnesses e. otherwise seriously jeopardizing an investigation or unduly delaying a (
) The court may extend the period for sending notice for additional intervals
days if provided with written certification from a supervisory official in the headquarters office of the seizing agency (Warrants and Forfeiture Section) that the conditions in paragraph (
) are present. (

) Notice must be sent to all persons whose identities and addresses are ably ascertainable and whose rights and interests in the seized property will could be affected by the forfeiture. These include all possessors, owners, lienholders. (

) Notice must include the following: a. a description of the property seized b. the time, place, and cause of the seizure c. the procedure and rights to contest the forfeiture d. the newspaper in which the notice of seizure is to be published and the dates of publication e. the final claim date Internal Revenue Manual

) Contraband or other property that the person from whom the property was seized may not legally possess will not be returned. (

and Exhibit
, Forfeiture Letter/Notice of Intent to Forfeit contain model notice letters that may be revised to meet individual circum- stances, but should not contain less information than they presently (
) Notice of seizure of the property must be published once a week for three secutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the judicial district of Notice of where the property was seized. (

) Notice of seizures must describe the seized property and state when, why, and from whom it was seized, and set forth the deadline for filing a To ensure the legal sufficiency of the published notice of seizure, a CT Attorney may include suggested wording in the Law and Fact Exhibit
, Notice of Seizure is a suggested format for the notice of seizure. (
) Notice to interested parties should be sent prior to, or contemporaneously the publication of notice of seizure. (

) Any person claiming property seized in an administrative forfeiture may file a claim with the SAC of the field office responsible for the refer the matter to a US district court for a judicial judgment. A bond is not required when filing a claim relative to an administrative forfeiture. (
) A claim may not be filed later than
days after the date the notice letter is mailed, except that if the letter is not received, then a claim may be filed for Filing a later than
days after the date of final publication of notice of seizure. If claim date falls on a weekend or holiday, it may be extended to the next workday. (
) The filing of a claim does not have any effect on the publication of the of seizure. (
) The forfeiture date is
days after the date of final publication of notice of seizure. If the forfeiture date falls on a weekend or holiday, it may be the Forfeiture to the next workday. (

Any person claiming property seized in an administrative forfeiture proceeding may file a claim with the SAC of the field office responsible for the forfeiture to refer the matter to a US district court for a judicial judgment. A bond is not required when filing a claim relative to an administrative forfeiture.
A claim must be made under oath subject to the penalty of perjury and:
mentary evidence of such interest if available) and state that the claim not frivolous
) A claim need not be made in any particular form. (
) Claim forms written in easily understandable language must be provided on Form of Claim request. The Executive Office of Asset Forfeiture, Department of the Directive Number
and Exhibit
, Seized Asset Claim Form contain model claim forms. (
) The AFC will include a claim form with the notice sent to interested parties.
) When a claim is received, the AFC will make sure the claim is sufficient (
) forwarding it to the US Attorney’s Office. If the claim form is incomplete or Review of Sufficiency of does not meet the statutory requirements set forth in subsection
, Claim AFC must notify the claimant, as soon as possible and allow a reasonable to comply. (
) If the requirements for the claim are not met within the time allowed, the shall be void and the administrative forfeiture shall proceed as though the claim was not submitted. (
) When a sufficient claim is received, the administrative forfeiture will be terminated and the claim forwarded by letter from the SAC to the Attorney’s Office.
) If no one files a claim for the seized property requesting a judicial (
) tion of the forfeiture within the specified time period, a Form

c. any property, once a claim is filed in the administrative forfeiture proceed- ing
Asset Seizure and (
) Formal civil judicial forfeiture proceedings are initiated by the filing of a complaint against the property pursuant to Supplemental Rule C(
). Forfeiture (

) A complaint for forfeiture should contain: a. the basis for the court’s jurisdiction b. a description of the property that is the subject of the forfeiture action c. a statement showing the property is subject to the jurisdiction of the district court d. the place of seizure e. the date of seizure and the seizing agency f. the circumstances from which the forfeiture claim arises g. an allegation the property is forfeitable to the United States h. a request for such relief as the court deems proper (
) A complaint for forfeiture must be filed not later than
days after a claim been filed. If a complaint for forfeiture is not filed within
days after a has been filed, the seized property must be returned and no further action affect the civil forfeiture of the property in connection with the underlying offense can be initiated. (
) Instead of, or in addition to the filing of a civil forfeiture complaint within
days, the government may include a forfeiture count or allegation in a indictment. (
) The civil forfeiture statutes do not specify a deadline for filing a civil complaint in a purely judicial investigation (that was never an investigation). The
-day (
-day in adoptive investigations) deadline to notice to interested parties does not apply in judicial investigations. A able interpretation is that a complaint should be filed within

days from date of seizure. Consult with the responsible AUSA for the local policy or recent court investigations regarding the deadline for filing a civil forfeiture complaint in a purely judicial investigation. (
) If the property subject to forfeiture has not previously been seized, it is seized pursuant to the warrant of arrestin rem, (see subsection
, In Warrants of Arrest In Rem). Guidance and procedures for the preparation, planning, execution, and return of process for warrants of arrests in rem contained in TEOAF Directive
, Execution of Warrants of Arrest In Rem Treasury Law Enforcement Agencies. (

) If the execution of the warrant of arrest in rem requires intrusion into an where there is a legitimate expectation of privacy, entry into the area can be made with a search warrant or consent of the persons whose rights affected. (

) After a complaint for forfeiture is filed against real property, a notice of the complaint is posted on the property and served on the property owner, with a copy of the complaint. If real property has been posted in this is not necessary for the court to issue a warrant of arrest in rem, or to other action to establish jurisdiction over the property. (
) Upon application, a writ of entry may be obtained for the purpose of ing an inspection and inventory of real property. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
F
Formal civil judicial forfeiture proceedings are initiated by the filing of complaint against the property pursuant to Supplemental Rule C(2).
(07-25-2007) Execution of Arrest In Rem Warrant
page
) When a complaint for forfeiture is filed against real property, a notice of lis (

) pendens should be prepared by the US Attorney’s Office and filed with the Lis Pendens local official who is responsible for recording deeds. A lis pendens is a that describes the real property and states the United States has an interest it as a result of the pending litigation. The effect of a lis pendens is to a bona fide sale of the property or its refinancing pending the outcome of forfeiture litigation. (

) State laws governs when a lis pendens may be filed. Most states require a pending court action involving the property. In these jurisdictions, either a forfeiture complaint must be filed, or an indictment, information, or criminal complaint obtained listing the property as subject to forfeiture. (
) The filing of a lis pendens is not considered a seizure.
) Notice of the civil forfeiture action is published in a newspaper of general (
) lation, generally once a week for three consecutive weeks. Notice and Processing (

) Personal notice of civil forfeiture action must also be served on all persons of Civil Forfeiture Action whose identities and addresses are known or reasonably ascertainable and whose rights and interest in the property will be affected by the lawsuit.
) The burden of proof in a civil judicial forfeiture action is on the government (
) establish, by a preponderance of the evidence, that the property is subject Burden of Proof forfeiture. (

) A complaint for forfeiture cannot be dismissed on the ground that there was not adequate evidence at the time the complaint was filed to establish the feitability of the property. Evidence gathered after the filing of a complaint forfeiture may be used to establish that the property is subject to forfeiture. (
) If the claimant raises an “innocent owner” defense, the claimant has the burden of proving that defense by a preponderance of the evidence.
) When an owner/violator consents to the forfeiture or the government (
) a civil forfeiture action (an Order of Forfeiture) the court enters judgment. Judgment/Order of Forfeiture
page 11

State laws governs when a lis pendens may be filed. Most states require a pending court action involving the property. In these jurisdictions, either a civil forfeiture complaint must be filed, or an indictment, information, or criminal complaint obtained listing the property as subject to forfeiture.

Personal notice of civil forfeiture action must also be served on all persons whose identities and addresses are known or reasonably ascertainable and whose rights and interest in the property will be affected by the lawsuit.
When an owner/violator consents to the forfeiture or the government prevails in a civil forfeiture action (an Order of Forfeiture) the court enters judgment.
